image.altText: Business people walk outside the Reserve Bank of Australia.

items.synopsis: The Reserve Bank has increased the cash rate to 4.1 per cent at its June meeting, citing "persistent" and "ongoing" high inflation. It's the highest cash rate since April 2012. Follow live.

title.children: Reserve Bank lifts cash rate to 4.1pc, but won't rule out 'further tightening' to tackle inflation

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Have the banks passed on the rise yet?  - Gordon from Canberra. Hi Gordon, I'm not Gareth but I can answer this for you. None of the big four banks have passed on the increase juuuust yet — anecdotally, I've noticed they've been taking longer and longer to announce the changes the more rate rises we've had. After last month's meeting, it took the big four banks two days before they announced their decision, with NAB moving first, followed by ANZ. Meanwhile if you want to suss out what your mortgage repayments might look like if your bank increases their interest rates, scroll down the blog for a handy calculator (or to save your thumb the pain, I've also linked it here ).
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Have the banks passed on the rate rise?

children.content: Have the banks passed on the rise yet?
- Gordon from Canberra
Hi Gordon, I'm not Gareth but I can answer this for you.
None of the big four banks have passed on the increase juuuust yet — anecdotally, I've noticed they've been taking longer and longer to announce the changes the more rate rises we've had.
After last month's meeting, it took the big four banks two days before they announced their decision, with NAB moving first, followed by ANZ.

Meanwhile if you want to suss out what your mortgage repayments might look like if your bank increases their interest rates, scroll down the blog for a handy calculator (or to save your thumb the pain,
I've also linked it here

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Hi Gareth, the RBA has said the higher wages is part of the reason to hike rates, but the treasurer says increasing the minimum wage isn't inflationary. Who is correct? (Thanks for the question inspiration Kate) - Patrick. Hi Patrick, Last week, the Fair Work Commission said it was confident the coming increases in the minimum wage and award rates of pay would only make a "modest" contribution to wage growth in 2023-24 and "will not cause or contribute to any wage-price spiral." Phil Lowe has also acknowledged that wages haven't been driving inflation up to this point. However, he says that doesn't mean wages won't start to push inflation higher if they start to get away from us. Here's what he said in today's statement about wages specifically: "Wages growth has picked up in response to the tight labour market and high inflation. Growth in public sector wages is expected to pick up further and the annual increase in award wages was higher than it was last year. "At the aggregate level, wages growth is still consistent with the inflation target, provided that productivity growth picks up." That last sentence says the wage growth we're seeing at the moment won't prevent the RBA from getting inflation back down into the 2% to 3% target range over time, as long as we see productivity growth pick up.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The RBA and Treasurer aren't necessarily contradicting each other

children.content: Hi Gareth, the RBA has said the higher wages is part of the reason to hike rates, but the treasurer says increasing the minimum wage isn't inflationary. Who is correct? (Thanks for the question inspiration Kate)
- Patrick
Hi Patrick,

Last week, the Fair Work Commission said it was confident the coming increases in the minimum wage and award rates of pay would only make a "modest" contribution to wage growth in 2023-24 and "will not cause or contribute to any wage-price spiral."
Phil Lowe has also acknowledged that wages haven't been driving inflation
up to this point.
However, he says that doesn't mean wages won't start to push inflation higher if they start to get away from us.
Here's what he said in today's statement about wages specifically:

"Wages growth has picked up in response to the tight labour market and high inflation. Growth in public sector wages is expected to pick up further and the annual increase in award wages was higher than it was last year.
"At the aggregate level, wages growth is still consistent with the inflation target, provided that productivity growth picks up."

That last sentence says the wage growth we're seeing at the moment won't prevent the RBA from getting inflation back down into the 2% to 3% target range over time, as long as we see productivity growth pick up.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext:
If only 1/3 of properties in Australia have mortgages - surely continuing to rise interest rates for a small percentage of people is a poor way of controlling inflation? 
Have they considered other methods of lowering inflation that doesn't disproportionally impact a certain population? - Mick. I think we do need to be more creative in how we combat inflation. A couple of months ago, I wrote about an idea that John Maynard Keynes came up with to control inflation during WWII. Friedrich Hayek, the Austrian economist who really detested Keynes's influence on policymakers, even had to admit the idea was "ingenious." Now, the possibility of using an idea like this would depend on the nature of the problem that's causing the inflation, and the nature of the inflation itself, but I think it helps to open one's mind to all possibilities - so we can see the world with fresh eyes sometimes. Could something like this work in the future?
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Alternative tools to tackle inflation?

featuredLink.title: Is there a better way to kill inflation than raising interest rates?

children.content:
If only 1/3 of properties in Australia have mortgages - surely continuing to rise interest rates for a small percentage of people is a poor way of controlling inflation? 
Have they considered other methods of lowering inflation that doesn't disproportionally impact a certain population?
- Mick
I think we
do
need to be more creative in how we combat inflation.
A couple of months ago, I wrote about an idea that John Maynard Keynes came up with to control inflation during WWII.
Friedrich Hayek, the Austrian economist who really detested Keynes's influence on policymakers, even had to admit the idea was "ingenious."

Now, the possibility of using an idea like this would depend on the nature of the problem that's causing the inflation, and the nature of the inflation itself, but I think it helps to open one's mind to all possibilities - so we can see the world with fresh eyes sometimes.
Could something like this work in the future?

image.altText: A woman in glasses sitting in a power wheelchair.

image.altText: Chau with his mother-in-law, wife Trang and son Daniel.

image.altText: A young man.

image.altText: Two middle aged women leaning together with big smiles

image.altText: A drone shot of rows of houses in Shell Cove, Wollongong's south.

title.children: How much extra could mortgage repayments be, now that the cash rate is 4.1 per cent?

image.altText: The roots of a branch photographed against the cracked, dry earth.

image.altText: A man with long, blonde, curly hair, poses and smiles at a camera, wearing a pattern shirt, standing in front of a window.
